attributes.name: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site
attributes.description: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site features a reconstructed 1840s adobe fur trading post on the mountain branch of the Santa Fe Trail where traders, trappers, travelers, and the Cheyenne and Arapaho tribes came together in peaceful terms for trade. Today, living historians recreate the sights, sounds, and smells of the past with guided tours, demonstrations and special events.
attributes.directions: The park is accessed via U.S. Highway 50 and Highway 194. From La Junta, Colorado on U.S. Highway 50, take Colorado Highway 109 north 1 mile to Colorado Highway 194, then east on Colorado Highway 194 six miles to the fort. From Las Animas, Colorado, on U.S. Highway 50, take Colorado Highway 194 west 13 miles. Set your GPS to 35110 State Highway 194 E., La Junta, CO.

operating_hours.description:
Summer Hours (Memorial Day Weekend to Indigenous Peoples' Day)
The fort is open from 8:00 am to 5:30 pm. The gate is open from 7:00 am to 5:30 pm.

Winter Hours (the day after Indigenous Peoples' Day to the day before Memorial Day Weekend)
The fort is open from 9:00 am to 4:00 pm, except on Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day, when the fort will be closed. The gate is open from 7:00 am to 4:00 pm, except on Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day.
operating_hours.name: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site

images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: Bent's Old Fort in background with wagon in front; fall yellow cottonwood leaves in foreground
images.caption: For much of its 16-year history, the fort was the only major permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and the Mexican settlements.

images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: Bent's Old Fort with shortgrass prairie in foreground and blue sky and clouds above
images.caption: For much of its 16-year history, the fort was the only major permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and the Mexican settlements.

images.title: Open hearth cooking in the fort kitchen
images.altText: Cooking in fort kitchen
images.caption: Buffalo meat is broiled in the reflector oven as was done historically in the 1840s.

images.title: Fur trapper explains the work of the 1830s.
images.altText: Fur trapper in camp
images.caption: Special events bring the past alive with encampments, fort trade and Plains Indian life.

images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: Bent's Old Fort with shortgrass prairie, tepee and wagon in foreground and blue sky & clouds above
images.caption: For much of its 16-year history, the fort was the only major permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and the Mexican settlements.

images.title: A Lakota warrior barters with the traders in the fort plaza
images.altText: Plains Indian trade in plaza
images.caption: Trade with a Lakota warrior for trade goods from around the world.

images.title: Swivel cannon is fired using 18th century drill
images.altText: Swivel cannon firing
images.caption: The fort's security depended on its ability to resist attack.

images.title: Hiking the Santa Fe Trail
images.altText: HIkers follow behind the fort's wagon on the Santa Fe Trail
images.caption: The Santa Fe Trail Encampment features a hike with the fort's wagon down the original Santa Fe Trail.

images.title: Santa Fe Trail Encampment and Trail Hike
images.altText: Interpreters and volunteers in period clothing on horseback and in wagons; group of people standing
images.caption: The Park features the Santa Fe Trail Encampment during certain years. Historical interpreters bring the fort to life. Visitors can hike 3 miles down the original Santa Fe Trail with the fort's wagons.

attributes.name: Black Canyon Of The Gunnison National Park
attributes.description: Big enough to be overwhelming, still intimate enough to feel the pulse of time, Black Canyon of the Gunnison exposes you to some of the steepest cliffs, oldest rock, and craggiest spires in North America. With two million years to work, the Gunnison River, along with the forces of weathering, has sculpted this vertical wilderness of rock, water, and sky.
attributes.directions: 7 miles north on CO Highway 347 from the intersection with U.S. Highway 50 east of Montrose. Physical/GPS address is - 9800 Hwy 347, Montrose, CO 81401

operating_hours.description:
The park is open 24 hours a day, every day, and no entry reservation is needed. The South Rim Road is open to vehicles from early April to mid-November. In winter, the South Rim Road is open to Gunnison Point. The remainder of the road is closed to vehicles, but open to cross country skiing and snowshoeing.

South Rim Visitor Center hours are listed on the Basic Information page.
operating_hours.name: South Rim

operating_hours.description: The park is open 24 hours a day. North Rim Road is open intermittently in Summer and Fall. North Rim Road and ranger station are closed in winter. The road typically closes late November and reopens mid-April.
operating_hours.name: North Rim

operating_hours.description: East Portal Road is closed in winter. The road typically closes mid-November and reopens mid-April.
operating_hours.name: East Portal

images.title: Black Canyon near Tomichi Point
images.altText: Black Canyon near Tomichi Point
images.caption: Black Canyon near Tomichi Point

images.title: Black Canyon near Painted Wall
images.altText: Black Canyon near Painted Wall
images.caption: Black Canyon near Painted Wall

attributes.name: California National Historic Trail
attributes.description: Follow in the footsteps of over 250,000 emigrants who traveled to the gold fields and rich farmlands of California during the 1840s and 1850s: the greatest mass migration in American history. The California National Historic Trail is over 5,000 miles long and covers portions of 10 states. Step into history along more than 1,000 miles of ruts and traces from travelers and their overland wagons.
attributes.directions: Those portions of the California National Historic Trail authorized by Congress include nearly 2,000 miles of historic trail that was once the primary "road" taken by farmers, enterprising business managers, gold-seekers, and fortune hunters who chose to make a new life on the California frontier. The route passes through ten states from Missouri to California.

operating_hours.description: The California National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operating_hours.name: California National Historic Trail

images.title: Wagon at Register Rock in City of Rocks National Reserve
images.altText: A white canvas wagon sits in front of a large rock buttress with mountains in the distance.
images.caption: Wagon at Register Rock in City of Rocks National Reserve

images.title: A creek in Carlin Canyon, Nevada on the California Trail
images.altText: A still creek winds through brown rolling hills.
images.caption: A creek in Carlin Canyon, Nevada on the California Trail

images.title: Trail ruts on through Humboldt Wells in Nevada
images.altText: A dirt road passes through sagebrush and a white post with a mountain in the background.
images.caption: Trail ruts on through Humboldt Wells in Nevada

images.title: Devil's Gate, Wyoming
images.altText: A rock buttress with a notch in it surrounded by sagebrush flats.
images.caption: Devil's Gate was an important emigrant landmark in Wyoming.

images.title: View of West Pass on Carson Route
images.altText: Pine trees partly obscure a distant mountain lake with snow-capped mountains.
images.caption: View of West Pass on the Carson Route of the California NHT.

attributes.name: Colorado National Monument
attributes.description: Colorado National Monument preserves one of the grand landscapes of the American West. But this treasure is much more than a monument. Towering monoliths exist within a vast plateau and canyon panorama. You can experience sheer-walled, red rock canyons along the twists and turns of Rim Rock Drive, where you may spy bighorn sheep and soaring eagles.
attributes.directions: Driving Westbound on Highway I-70 towards Grand Junction, Exit 31 (Horizon Drive). Follow signs through Grand Junction to the east entrance. The visitor center and campground are 19 miles from the east entrance. Eastbound on Highway I-70 take Exit 19 (Fruita). Turn south on Highway 340 to the west entrance, which is approximately three miles from Fruita. The visitor center and campground are four miles up from the west entrance.

operating_hours.description: The Monument is open 24 hours a day year-round. Rim Rock Road is only closed for poor road conditions (snow, ice, rock fall, etc). For updates on storm or temporary closures call the park hotline at (970) 858-3617 ext 402.
operating_hours.name: Colorado National Monument

images.title: Independence Monument
images.altText: View of Independence Monument with Grand Valley in background. Taken from Rim Rock Rock Drive.
images.caption: View of Independence Monument with Grand Valley in background. Taken from Rim Rock Rock Drive.

images.title: Monument Canyon
images.altText: Monument Canyon with red rock walls and a valley with rolling landscape covered with pinyon trees
images.caption: Monument Canyon

images.title: Colorado National Monument Visitor Center
images.altText: Visitor Center with American Flag
images.caption: Colorado National Monument Visitor Center

images.title: Rim Rock Drive
images.altText: Looking down from canyon rim at a portion of the historic Rim Rock Drive
images.caption: Rim Rock Drive was built in the 1930s by the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC).

images.title: Balanced Rock
images.altText: Rock spire with large boulder balancing on top.
images.caption: Balanced Rock

attributes.name: Curecanti National Recreation Area
attributes.description: Curecanti National Recreation Area is a series of three reservoirs along the once wild Gunnison River. The reservoirs that make up Curecanti today are a destination for water-based recreation high in the Rocky Mountains. Best known for salmon and trout fishing, Curecanti also offers opportunities for hiking, boating, camping, and bird watching.
attributes.directions: U.S. Highway 50 runs the length of Curecanti between Montrose and Gunnison. The recreation area is also accessed from CO Highway 149 and CO Highway 92.

operating_hours.description: Open 24 hours per day, 365 days per year, weather permitting.
operating_hours.name: Recreation Area

images.title: Dillon Pinnacles, Curecanti National Recreation Area
images.altText: Dillon Pinnacles, Curecanti National Recreation Area
images.caption: Dillon Pinnacles, Curecanti National Recreation Area

images.title: Blue Mesa Reservoir, Curecanti National Recreation Area
images.altText: Blue Mesa Reservoir, Curecanti National Recreation Area
images.caption: Blue Mesa Reservoir, Curecanti National Recreation Area

attributes.name: Dinosaur National Monument
attributes.description: Dinosaurs once roamed here. Their fantastic remains are still visibly embedded in the rocks. Today, the mountains, desert, and untamed rivers flowing in deep canyons support an array of life. Petroglyphs hint at earlier cultures. Later, homesteaders and outlaws found refuge here. Whether your passion is science, adventure, history or scenery, Dinosaur offers much to explore.
attributes.directions: Dinosaur National Monument is located on the Colorado and Utah border with a parts of the monument in both states. Dinosaur fossils are not visible in the Colorado portion of the monument - only on the Utah side. The Quarry Visitor Center and Exhibit Hall (where you see the dinosaur fossils) are located approximately 7 miles north of Jensen, Utah.

operating_hours.description: The outdoor areas in the monument is open 24 hours per day. Facilities such as visitor centers and the Quarry Exhibit Hall have specific hours of operation. Visit the Operating Hours & Seasons page for more information on facility hours. Some areas of the monument may close in the winter due to snow.
operating_hours.name: Dinosaur National Monument Hours

images.title: Camarasaurus Skull
images.altText: the fossilized skull of camarasaurus dinosaur
images.caption: Over 1500 fossilized bones of various dinosaurs are still embedded in the cliff face including a skull and several neck vertebrae of a camarasaurus

images.title: Camarasaurus Hump Specimen
images.altText: Large bones resembling legs, ribs and the vertebrae of a neck embed grayish brown rock.
images.caption: Fossils from a camarasaurus dinosaur display the well articulated specimens still found in the rock in the Quarry Exhibit Hall.

images.title: Steamboat Rock and the Green River in Echo Park
images.altText: the rocky pinnacle of Steamboat Rock rises over the Green River
images.caption: Steamboat Rock rises above the Green River in Echo Park

images.title: McKee Springs Petroglyphs
images.altText: Fremont rock art at McKee Springs
images.caption: The Fremont people left petroglyphs on many of the rock cliffs within Dinosaur National Monument including those at McKee Springs

images.title: Mitten Park from Harpers Corner
images.altText: view of a river flowing through a deep canyon
images.caption: Hikers arriving at the end of the Harpers Corner Trail are rewarded with a view of the Mitten Park Fault, Green River and the Yampa River Canyons

images.title: Night Sky over Tent
images.altText: the star filled sky above a tent
images.caption: Dinosaur's dark skies provides dramatic views of the Milky Way Galaxy

images.title: Rocky Mountain Bighorns
images.altText: A bighorn sheep lamb stands in front of a bighorn ewe.
images.caption: Visitors to Dinosaur may also see its diversity of wildlife including Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep.

images.title: Floating Rapids
images.altText: A green rubber raft floats over a rapid on a brown colored river in front of multi-colored mountains
images.caption: Rapids like those in Split Mountain Canyon challenge and thrill rafters on the Green River.

attributes.name: Florissant Fossil Beds National Monument
attributes.description: Beneath a grassy mountain valley in central Colorado lies one of the richest and most diverse fossil deposits in the world. Petrified redwood stumps up to 14 feet wide and thousands of detailed fossils of insects and plants reveal the story of a very different, prehistoric Colorado.
attributes.directions: Visitors traveling north/south on I-25: Exit at US 24 West, travel 35 miles to town of Florissant, then follow signs two miles south on Teller County Road 1 to the Visitor Center. Visitors traveling from town of Cripple Creek: Follow Teller County Road 1 north for 16 miles.

operating_hours.description: Spring, Summer, and Fall Hours (March 14, 2021 - November 6, 2021) are 9:00 AM - 5 PM
operating_hours.name: Spring, Summer, and Fall Hours

images.title: Big Stump
images.altText: Fossil redwood stump
images.caption: Walk the Petrified Trail Loop to see fossil redwood stumps

images.title: Ancient Wasp Fossil
images.altText: palaeovespa, ancient wasp
images.caption: Captured 34 million years ago, this ancient wasp and other insects are on display at Florissant Fossil Beds NM.

images.title: Hornbek Homestead Visitors
images.altText: Visitors at Hornbek Homestead
images.caption: Visitors explore the Hornbek Homestead, built in 1878.

images.title: Junior Rangers
images.altText: Junior Rangers in Visitors Center
images.caption: Youth of all ages participate in the Junior Rangers program at the Monument.

images.title: Self Guided Trails
images.altText: View of the Florissant valley with grassy meadows and mountains in the distance
images.caption: View from the top of the self-guided Geologic Trail

attributes.name: Great Sand Dunes National Park & Preserve
attributes.description: Open 24/7 year round! There are no reservations to visit or limit on the number of visitors in the park and preserve, but there is currently limited capacity in the visitor center. The tallest dunes in North America are the centerpiece in a diverse landscape of grasslands, wetlands, forests, alpine lakes, and tundra. Explore this website to learn more!

emailAddresses.description: Email a ranger to get your questions answered.

attributes.directions: To access the main park area, including the Dunes Parking Lot, Visitor Center, and Pinon Flats Campground, take US 160 to CO 150 from the south, or CO 17 to Lane 6 to CO 150 from the west. The national park is at the north end of CO 150.

operating_hours.description: The park and preserve are open 24/7 all year
operating_hours.name: Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve

images.title: Dunes and Crestone Peaks at Sunset
images.altText: Grasslands, large dunes, and snow-capped peaks at sunset
images.caption: The view at the park entrance contrasts giant dunes and snow-capped mountains.

images.title: Girls Sand Sledding
images.altText: Girls Sand Sledding
images.caption: Rent specially designed sand sleds to slide on the dry sand.  Note: cardboard, snow sleds, saucers, and other items don't slide on dry sand.

images.title: Elk, Grasslands, Dunes, and Sangre de Cristo Mountains
images.altText: Elk, Grasslands, Dunes, and Sangre de Cristo Mountains
images.caption: Elk are sometimes seen by visitors along the park entrance road or County Lane 6, primarily fall through spring.

images.title: Lower Sand Creek Lake, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.altText: Lower Sand Creek Lake, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.caption: Spectacular alpine lakes are part of the backcountry of Great Sand Dunes National Preserve

images.title: Upper Sand Creek Basin, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.altText: Upper Sand Creek Basin, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.caption: Sand Creek Basin, part of Great Sand Dunes National Preserve, contains lush forests and alpine lakes.

images.title: Fall Colors Along Mosca Creek, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.altText: Fall Colors Along Mosca Creek, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.caption: Fall is a pretty time to visit the park, with great colors and generally nice weather.

images.title: Gold Cottonwoods, Dunes, and Cleveland Peak
images.altText: Gold cottonwood trees, large dunes, a silver cloud, and snow-capped mountain
images.caption: Experiencing Great Sand Dunes in the quieter seasons of fall and winter can be a rewarding experience.

images.title: Girl Floating Medano Creek
images.altText: A teen girl sits on a floatation device
images.caption: Visitors can float Medano Creek's waves during late spring peak flow, in years of good snowpack

attributes.name: Hovenweep National Monument
attributes.description: Once home to over 2,500 people, Hovenweep includes six prehistoric villages built between A.D. 1200 and 1300. Explore a variety of structures, including multistory towers perched on canyon rims and balanced on boulders. The construction and attention to detail will leave you marveling at the skill and motivation of the builders.
attributes.directions: Do not use GPS to find your way. There are numerous paved and dirt roads intersecting each other in this remote corner of Utah. The Hovenweep Visitor Center is located 40-45 miles from Cortez, Colorado, and Blanding and Bluff, Utah. Follow driving directions on our webpage.

operating_hours.description: Hovenweep National Monument is generally open year-round. Park trails are open only sunrise to sunset.
operating_hours.name: Open sunrise to sunset

images.title: Milky Way at Square Tower Group
images.altText: a stone structure at night with the Milky Way arcing overhead
images.caption: Hovenweep National Monument was designated an International Dark Sky Park in 2014.

images.title: Claretcup Cactus
images.altText: a bright red cactus flower
images.caption: Claretcup Cactus is a common plant at Hovenweep National Monument

images.title: Stronghold House
images.altText: a stone structure resting on a cliff edge
images.caption: Stronghole House is one of several structures at the Square Tower Group

images.title: Cajon Unit
images.altText: a stone structure with blue sky and clouds overhead
images.caption: The Cajon Unit is one of several outlying units at Hovenweep National Monument.

images.title: Collared Lizard
images.altText: a green lizard with yellow head, yellow spots and black collar
images.caption: Collard lizards are one of many species that call Hovenweep home.

images.title: Holly Group
images.altText: remains of a stone structure with wood beams on the edge of a canyon
images.caption: The Holly Group is one of Hovenweep's outlying sites, but worth the drive or hike.

attributes.name: Mesa Verde National Park
attributes.description: This wild landscape of deep canyons and expansive vistas is home to over a thousand species, including several that live nowhere else on earth. For over 700 years, the Ancestral Pueblo people built thriving communities on the mesas and in the cliffs of Mesa Verde. Today, the park protects the rich cultural heritage of 26 tribes and offers visitors a spectacular window into the past.
attributes.directions: Mesa Verde National Park is in Southwestern Colorado. The park entrance is along Highway 160, between the towns of of Cortez and Mancos, Colorado. (10 miles east of Cortez; 9 miles west of Mancos; and about 35 miles west of Durango, Colorado.) Once you enter the park, the first view of a cliff dwelling is 21 miles (approximately 45 minutes) along a steep, narrow, and winding road.

exceptions.name: New Years Day - The park is open but all facilities are closed.
Thanksgiving Day - The park is open but all facilities are closed.
Christmas Day - The park is open but all facilities are closed.

operating_hours.description: The park is open, but services are limited. For more information on services, please visit https://www.nps.gov/meve/planyourvisit/ops_updates_covid19.htm.
operating_hours.name: Mesa Verde National Park Hours

images.title: Cliff Palace
images.altText: Large cliff dwelling in cliff alcove
images.caption: Cliff Palace, Mesa Verde's Largest Cliff Dwelling

images.title: Step House
images.altText: Park visitors visiting a cliff dwelling
images.caption: Visitors enjoying Step House, on Wetherill Mesa

images.title: Balcony House
images.altText: A cliff dwelling within a cliff alcove seen from across a canyon
images.caption: View of Balcony House from the Soda Canyon Overlook

images.title: Square Tower House
images.altText: View of cliff dwelling from above a canyon
images.caption: Square Tower House from overlook along the Mesa Top Loop

images.title: View of Spruce Tree House
images.altText: View of cliff dwelling from across canyon
images.caption: Spruce Tree House

images.title: Spruce Tree House
images.altText: Within a cliff dwelling
images.caption: Spruce Tree House, Mesa Verde's third largest and best preserved cliff dwelling

images.title: Mesa Verde Visitor and Research Center
images.altText: Visitor center entrance with sculpture of Ancestral Pueblo climber in front plaza.
images.caption: Stop by the Mesa Verde Visitor & Research Center at the park entrance where park staff will help you plan your visit.

attributes.name: Old Spanish National Historic Trail
attributes.description: Follow the routes of mule pack trains across the Southwest on the Old Spanish National Historic Trail between Santa Fe, New Mexico, and Los Angeles, California. New Mexican traders moved locally produced merchandise across what are now six states to exchange for mules and horses.
attributes.directions: You can visit many sites of the Old Spanish National Historic Trail over the 2,680-mile historic route that crosses 6 states.

operating_hours.description: There are many places of history and commemoration on the Old Spanish National Historic Trail to visit. Museums, interpretive centers, and historic sites provide information and interpretation. Please contact each site before you go to obtain current information on closures, changes in hours, and fees.
operating_hours.name: Old Spanish National Historic Trail

images.title: Santa Rosa de Lima de Abiquiú, Abiquiú, New Mexico
images.altText: crumbling adobe structure with blue sky
images.caption: Santa Rosa de Lima de Abiquiú provided a way station for travelers along the Old Spanish Trail in the 1800s. It is privately owned by the Archdiocese of Santa Fe.

images.title: Rio Chama River, Abiquiú, New Mexico
images.altText: hikers walk beside a river with cottonwoods alongside the river
images.caption: This section of the Rio Chama River, tributary of the Rio Grande, is located about six miles north of Abiquiú, New Mexico and flows through the Carson National Forest.

images.title: Sierra Blanca, San Luis Valley, Colorado
images.altText: desert scrub in foreground, spiky mountains in background, clouds
images.caption: Sierra Blanca is a prominent mountain in the Sangre de Cristo Range along San Luis Valley on Highway 17. Locating landmarks were essential to traveling the Old Spanish Trail.

images.title: San Rafael Swell, Utah
images.altText: desert scenery, dead tree, blue sky with puffy coulds
images.caption: The San Rafael Swell is a huge craggy geologic feature (an anticline), about 75 miles by 40 miles, located in south-central Utah approximately 30 miles west of Green River.

images.title: Virgin River Canyon, Arizona
images.altText: a river carves through the landscape, greenery in the foreground, mountains and redrock backdrop
images.caption: This section of the Virgin River Canyon Recreation Area is off Interstate 15 about 20 miles southwest of St. George, Utah and about 20 miles northeast of Mesquite, Nevada

images.title: Old Spanish Trail segment, Nevada
images.altText: rocky trail through desert with yucca, mountain in the background
images.caption: This trail segment is 5.25 miles, and is part of the Old Spanish Trail/Mormon Road Historic District, outside Blue Diamond, Clark County, Nevada.

images.title: Mojave Road, California
images.altText: trail through desert scrub with Joshua trees, mountains in the distance, puffy clouds
images.caption: Old Spanish Trail travelers used this section of the historic Mojave Road is within Mojave National Preserve.

attributes.name: Pony Express National Historic Trail
attributes.description: It is hard to believe that young men once rode horses to carry mail from Missouri to California in the unprecedented time of only 10 days. This relay system along the Pony Express National Historic Trail in eight states was the most direct and practical means of east-west communications before the telegraph.
attributes.directions: You can visit many sites of the Pony Express National Historic Trail over the 1,800-mile historic route that crosses 8 states.

operating_hours.description: The Pony Express National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a route that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operations and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operating_hours.name: Pony Express National Historic Trail

images.title: Simpson Spring NPEA rider, Utah
images.altText: A rider in a red vest on a horse in a grassy patch surrounded by sagebrush with clouds in the sky.
images.caption: A National Pony Express Association rider poses at Simpson Springs in Utah.

images.title: Devil's Gate, Wyoming
images.altText: A tall rock buttress with a cleft in the center sits behind a sagebrush covered valley.
images.caption: Devil's Gate was an important landmark on the trail in Wyoming.

images.title: Schelbourne Station, Nevada
images.altText: A footbridge leads to a dark steel silhouette of a Pony Express rider.
images.caption: A Pony Express rider silhouette can be found at the Schelbourne Station site in Nevada.

images.title: Fort Laramie NHS monument, Wyoming
images.altText: A tall obelisk monument with bronze plaques sits on a paved pathway in front of a building.
images.caption: A monument and plaque about the Pony Express can be found at Fort Laramie in Wyoming.

images.title: Stables at St. Joseph
images.altText: A large brick historic stable.
images.caption: Visit the historic stables in St. Joseph, Missouri.

attributes.name: Rocky Mountain National Park
attributes.description: Rocky Mountain National Park’s 415 square miles encompass and protect spectacular mountain environments. Enjoy Trail Ridge Road – which crests at over 12,000 feet including many overlooks to experience the subalpine and alpine worlds – along with over 300 miles of hiking trails, wildflowers, wildlife, starry nights, and fun times. In a world of superlatives, Rocky is on top!
attributes.directions: Driving from the east: from I-25, take US Hwy 34 or 36. Driving from the west: from I-70, take US Hwy 40 to Granby to US Hwy 34 to Grand Lake. From mid-October until late May, Trail Ridge Road between Estes Park and Grand Lake is closed to vehicles, so driving between the two takes ~4 hours. The closest airport is Denver International (DIA). There is no public transportation between nearby cities and the park.

operating_hours.description: While certain roads and facilities may be closed, the park is open 24 hours a day, 365 days a year.
operating_hours.name: Rocky Mountain National Park

images.title: Summer on the Tundra
images.altText: Yellow flowers bloom on tundra slopes with mountains in the background.
images.caption: Old Man of the Mountain bloom on Rocky's alpine tundra.

images.title: Trail Ridge Road
images.altText: Road sweeps across open tundra with mountains in background.
images.caption: Trail Ridge Road, the highest continuous paved road in the United States, let's visitors experience Rocky's alpine tundra.

images.title: Elk in Moraine Park
images.altText: A herd of elk stand in a meadow.
images.caption: In the fall, Rocky's elk gather together in groups for the mating season.

images.title: Horseshoe Park
images.altText: The moon sets below mountain peaks at sunrise.
images.caption: While the moon sets, the sun rises at Horseshoe Park, one of Rocky's beautiful meadows.

images.title: Longs Peak
images.altText: Longs Peak, covered in snow, against dark moody clouds.
images.caption: Longs Peak towers above Rocky Mountain National Park.

attributes.name: Sand Creek Massacre National Historic Site
attributes.description: The Sand Creek Massacre: profound, symbolic, spiritual, controversial, a site unlike any other in America. As 675 cavalrymen came around a prairie bend, the camps of Chiefs Black Kettle, White Antelope, and Left Hand lay in the valley before them. Chaotic, horrific, tumultuous, and bloody, the events of November 29, 1864 changed the course of history.
attributes.directions: The Sand Creek Massacre is located in Kiowa County, Colorado. To visit the site, follow Colorado State Highway 96 east off Highway 287 near Eads, or west off Highway 385 at Sheridan Lake. Near Chivington, turn north onto County Road 54/Chief White Antelope Way or at Brandon, turn north onto County Road 59. Follow these roads to their intersections with County Road W. The park entrance is along CR W a mile east (right) of CR 54 or several miles west (left) of CR 59. Eight miles of dirt/sand roads lead to the

operating_hours.description: Sand Creek Massacre NHS is open Thursday through Monday, 9:00 am to 4:00 pm, and closed Tuesday and Wednesday.
operating_hours.name: Sand Creek Massacre National Historic Site Hours

images.title: Cheyenne Lodges at Dawn
images.altText: Four white Indian lodges on a grassy plain.
images.caption: Cheyenne and Arapaho Lodges erected in commemoration of the 150th Year of the Sand Creek Massacre

images.title: Remembering the Past
images.altText: A lone tipi frame and two wayside signs stand in a snow-covered landscape
images.caption: A tipi frame is backlit by an evening sky.

images.title: Memorial at Sunset
images.altText: A stone memorial on the prairie with an evening sky in the background.
images.caption: Back lit clouds form an impressive backdrop to the stone memorial dedicated to the memory of the Sand Creek Massacre.

images.title: Sunset along Sand Creek
images.altText: The uppermost branches of leafless trees in a grassy plain are lit by the setting sun.
images.caption: The setting sun highlights trees along Sand Creek, forming a hauntingly beautiful landscape

images.title: Tipi Frame at Dusk
images.altText: A tipi frame is silhouetted by the evening sky.
images.caption: The silhouette of a lone tipi at dusk symbolizes the tragic events that occurred in 1864 and of the indomitable spirit of the Cheyenne and Arapaho people, who overcame the tragedy and continue to work with the NPS to preserve its memory and legacy.

images.title: Winter clouds over Sand Creek
images.altText: An expanse of winter prairie with brown grasses, leafless trees, and low clouds above.
images.caption: Winter on the Southeastern Colorado Plains can produce beautiful scenes such as this.

images.title: Fall Colors along the Big Sandy Creek
images.altText: A Sand Creek memorial plaque and fallen tree trunk with trees in fall color behind.
images.caption: The leaves of Cottonwood trees along the Sand Creek burst with color during the fall.

images.title: Snow on Monument Hill Overlook
images.altText: A wayside in the snow-covered foreground with a winter plain stretching behind.
images.caption: This tranquil winter view shows snow throughout the Sand Creek Valley.

attributes.name: Santa Fe National Historic Trail
attributes.description: You can almost hear the whoops and cries of "All's set!" as trail hands hitched their oxen to freight wagons carrying cargo between western Missouri and Santa Fe, New Mexico. Follow the Santa Fe National Historic Trail through five states and you'll find adventure and evidence of past travelers who made this remarkable trip before you!
attributes.directions: You can visit many sites of the Santa Fe National Historic Trail over the 900-mile historic route that crosses five states.

operating_hours.description: There are many places of history and commemoration on the Santa Fe National Historic Trail to visit. Museums, interpretive centers, and historic sites provide information and interpretation. Please contact each site before you go to obtain current information on closures, changes in hours, and fees.
operating_hours.name: Santa Fe National Historic Trail

images.title: Cimarron National Grassland
images.altText: Warm light from the setting sun gives an orange glow to a rock bluff overlooking a grassland.
images.caption: Visit Cimarron National Grassland to experience the Santa Fe Trail.

images.title: Neosho River Crossing, Council Grove
images.altText: A wide river with green grass parks on the side.
images.caption: The Neosho River in Council Grove was an important crossing on the trail.

images.title: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site, La Junta, Colorado
images.altText: emigrant wagons pulled by oxen and horses cross the prairie with people walking alongside
images.caption: After spending weeks crossing hundreds of miles of lonely and desolate prairie, a trading post appeared: a welcome respite where travelers could repair their wagon and trade for coffee, sugar, blankets, and ammunition.

images.title: Wagon Mound, Mora County, New Mexico
images.altText: desert landscape with a mountain that looks like a wagon from a distance, verdant green grasses
images.caption: Wagon Mound was a landmark on the Santa Fe Trail. Coming from Raton, New Mexico, travelers looked for this wagon-like hill to know that they were close to Santa Fe. Leave Interstate 25 at the village of Wagon Mound in Mora County to find this landmark.

images.title: Fort Union, New Mexico
images.altText: A stone path leads into the distance next to adobe ruins.
images.caption: The Santa Fe Trail traverses through Fort Union.

attributes.name: Yucca House National Monument
attributes.description: Through a continuing tradition of public and private cooperation, Yucca House National Monument preserves one of the largest archeological sites in SW Colorado. The unexcavated nature of the site preserves its integrity and beauty for future generations of scientists and visitors. Experience a sense of discovery by visiting a site that has remained largely untouched for the past 800 years!
attributes.directions: •From Cortez, take Hwy. 491 south approximately 8 miles. •Take a right on MC County Road B (green sign), which is a dirt road one mile south of MC Road C. •Drive 0.8 miles, crossing a paved road (MC Road 21), and take the next dirt road on the right (before the farmhouse on the left). •Follow this road north and west for 1.4 miles, and head towards a white ranch house with a red roof on the west horizon. •Once at the ranch house, Yucca House NM is on the left side if the driveway.

operating_hours.description: Open year-round, weather pending. No services are available.
operating_hours.name: Yucca House National Monument

images.title: Yucca House Spring
images.altText: Cattails with mesa in background.
images.caption: Cattails define marshy locations watered by springs.

images.title: View of Mesa Verde from Yucca House
images.altText: View of Mesa Verde landform
images.caption: View of Mesa Verde above from Yucca House in the valley below.

images.title: Walls of the Yucca House Pueblo
images.altText: Masonry walls seen through shrubbery
images.caption: Ancient walls of Yucca House still standing today.

images.title: Ancestral Puebloan Wall at Yucca House
images.altText: Close up view of an ancient wall at Yucca House
images.caption: View of an Ancestral Puebloan wall still standing at Yucca House.

images.title: Yucca House in Context
images.altText: View of  ancient wall in the center of agricultural land surrounding it.
images.caption: The Yucca House archeological site is surrounded by agricultural land today.
